title: How to Make Oreo Cheesecake

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 350 °F (177 °C).
steps.description: If you are using a dark, nonstick pan, lower the oven temperature to 325°F (162°C).

steps.headline: Mix together the 26 crushed Oreo cookies and melted butter in a food processor.
steps.description: Pulse the Oreo cookies in the food processor until you get fine crumbs first. Add the melted butter and blend again until smooth. The cookies need to be finely ground, sort of like coffee grounds. If they are too chunky, your crust won't hold together well. Save the remaining 10 cookies for the filling.

steps.headline: Press the cookie mixture into the prepared springform pan.
steps.description: Make sure that the crust is firmly packed into the pan, or it won't hold together. For a fancier touch, spread the mixture across the bottom of the pan first, then push it 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) up the sides.

steps.headline: Bake the crust for 8 to 10 minutes in the oven, then set it aside to cool.
steps.description: Do not remove the crust from the springform pan yet. It won't hold together until you add the cheesecake filling.

steps.headline: Beat the of cream cheese and sugar until blended.
steps.description: You can do this using an electric mixer or a food processor fitted with whisks. From time to time, pause the mixer, and scrape down the sides with a spatula; this will ensure that everything gets evenly mixed together.

steps.headline: Slowly add the eggs, one at a time.
steps.description: Mix the filling on low speed after each egg you add until it is blended before adding the next egg.

steps.headline: Fold in the sour cream and vanilla extract, and mix again.
steps.description: Make sure that the ingredients are evenly mixed throughout. There should be no streaks and swirls; everything should be consistent.

steps.headline: Roughly chop up the remaining Oreo cookies and stir them into the filling.
steps.description: Use a knife to chop the cookies into coarse crumbs; they can be as big or as small as you'd like. Gently stir them into the filling using a spatula.

steps.headline: Pour the filling into the crust.
steps.description: If you need to, use a spatula to help guide the filling into the crust. Smooth the top down with a spatula so that there aren't any ripples.

steps.headline: Bake the cheesecake for 55 to 60 minutes.
steps.description: The cake is ready when the center is almost set. To prevent the top of the cake from browning in the oven, tent a sheet of tin foil over the pan during the last 15 to 20 minutes of baking.

steps.headline: Let the cheesecake cool completely before taking it out of the pan.
steps.description: Once the cheesecake finishes baking, take it out of the oven and set it down. Run a knife around the rim of the pan. Let the cake cool completely before opening the pan and removing the rim. Leave the cake on the pan's base, however.

steps.headline: Decorate the cake, if desired, and refrigerate it for at least 4 hours before serving.
steps.description: There is enough cake to cut 16 slices. Cover and store any leftovers in the fridge for up to 3 days.To learn how to decorate your cake, click here.

steps.headline: Mix the crushed Oreos and melted butter in a food processor.
steps.description: Blend the cookies in the food processor first, until you get fine crumbs. Add the melted butter and blend again until the mixture is damp. The cookies need  be finely ground, sort of like coffee grounds. If the crumbs are too big, the crust won't wold together.

steps.headline: Spread the mixture across the bottom of a 9-inch (22.86 centimeters) springform pan.
steps.description: Pack the mixture down firmly or it won't hold together. Use a spatula to flatten and smooth it out.

steps.headline: Place the crust into the fridge to chill.
steps.description: This will help the crust hold together better. By the time you are done making the filling, it should be ready.

steps.headline: Beat the cream cheese, powdered sugar, and vanilla until everything is smooth and evenly combined.
steps.description: You can do this using a an electric mixer fitted with a paddle attachment. You can also do this using a hand-held mixer instead.

steps.headline: Gently fold in the frozen whipped cream topping.
steps.description: Thaw a frozen whipped cream topping (such as Cool Whip) and gently fold it into the mixture until everything is evenly combined.

steps.headline: Roughly chop up the remaining Oreos, and gently stir them into the mixture.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to chop up the Oreos. Don't worry about being too neat; the Oreos will likely crumble on their own. If you'd like a crunchier Oreo cheesecake, you can add in more Oreo cookies. Use a spoon or spatula to gently mix the cookies in.

steps.headline: Take the crust out of the fridge and scoop the filling into it.
steps.description: Use a spatula to spread the filling evenly across the crust. Don't add any decorations just yet. The cheesecake needs to set.

steps.headline: Cover the cheesecake tightly with a sheet of plastic wrap, then put it into the fridge.
steps.description: You can also leave it there overnight; the flavors will blend in together better.

steps.headline: Remove the cheesecake from the pan.
steps.description: Run a knife around the inside of the springform pan to loosen it, then carefully take the pan apart. Leave the cheesecake on the base of the pan.

steps.headline: Decorate the cheesecake, if desired, and serve it.
steps.description: There's enough cake to serve 16 people. If you have any leftovers, cover them and store them in the fridge for up to 3 days. To learn how to decorate your cake, click here.

steps.headline: Place the cheesecake onto a plate, and sure that it is completely cool.
steps.description: You will be adding whipped cream onto the cake. If it is still warm, the whipped cream will melt and make an oozy mess instead. Leave the cheesecake on the springform pan's base. You can put it onto a regular plate or onto a cardboard cake circle.

steps.headline: Consider covering the entire cake with frosting.
steps.description: This will help the cookie crumbs stick to it better. If you made a 2-inch (5.08 centimeters) high crust, leave that part uncovered. For an extra touch, mix some finely crumbled Oreo cookies (the texture of coffee grounds) into the whipped cream first. Apply the whipped cream with a spatula. If the frosting is too sweet for you, add a pinch of salt to it. This will help cut the sweetness.

steps.headline: Crumble a handful of Oreo cookies until they resemble coffee grounds.
steps.description: You need enough to cover the entire top of your cake. How thick that layer is depends entirely on your preference. Use a food processor or a blender to grind the cookies into a fine dust.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the ground Oreos over the top of the cake in an even layer.
steps.description: If you'd like, you can also press some into the sides of the cake as well. You can do this by cupping your hand, filling it with crumbs, and then gently pressing it against the side of the cake. When you are done, sweep any excess crumbs off the plate. If you are adding cookie crumbs to the side of the cake, you will need to coat it with frosting first.

steps.headline: Fill a piping bag with whipped cream.
steps.description: Use a star-shaped decorating tip for the bag. You can also use a can of whipped cream instead—the type that you spray out of a nozzle.

steps.headline: Pipe dollops of whipped cream all around the edge of the cake.
steps.description: If you have any whipped cream leftover, you can add another small dollop of it in the center of the cake. Aim to have about 16 dollops. This way, each dollop will get topped with one Oreo cookie.

steps.headline: Cut 8 Oreo cookies in half using a sharp knife.
steps.description: Be careful not to break them. You can also use mini Oreo cookies instead; this way, you won't have to cut them.

steps.headline: Place each Oreo half onto the dollops.
steps.description: If you don't have enough cookies, simply cut some more. These will serve as a guideline for cutting: each slice will get one cookie-topped dollop of whipped cream. If you put some whipped cream in the center, top it off with another Oreo cookie.

steps.headline: Consider chilling the cake before serving it.
steps.description: If you like your cheesecakes nice and cool, leave it in the fridge for 30 to 60 minutes. This will also help the whipped cream topping to set and harden.

steps.headline: Finished.
